title: TikTok Health Trends: True or False?
subtitle: With the time that young adults and teens spend on Tik Tok, it’s no surprise that trends often start there. When it comes to health trends, it’s important to consider whether a source is reputable or not. After all, anyone can become a content creator.
content:
With the time that young adults and teens spend on Tik Tok, it’s no surprise that trends often start there. When it comes to health trends, it’s important to consider whether a source is reputable or not. After all, anyone can become a content creator

Recently, several health trends have gained traction on TikTok, where 71.3 percent of users are aged 18-34. We’ll look at what experts say so you know what to avoid (and what might help.)

However, remember that the best resource is always a doctor — and getting an appointment at Qcare to get all your healthcare concerns answered is quick and easy!

Liquid chlorophyll for energy and weight loss

One recent trend shows TikTokers squirting green liquid chlorophyll into water and drinking it. Many claim to have increased energy and that it helps with weight loss.

Is it true?

While chlorophyll is an antioxidant, it doesn’t dissolve in water. That means what you’re ingesting is more likely to be chlorophyllin, and experts say there’s not enough evidence that either chlorophyll or chlorophyllin improves your health to bank on it.

If you want to get more chlorophyll, one of the best ways — and one known to be healthy — is to eat more leafy green vegetables. That’s a better route than liquid chlorophyll, according to doctors.

Mouth taping for snoring

Do you snore, have a dry mouth when you wake up or struggle with bad breath? If so, some TikTok influencers suggest using “mouth taping,” where you tape your mouth shut during the night.

Is it true?

This is one where doctors disagree. While nose-breathing can be helpful, taping your mouth shut is not how to manage a sleep issue. This approach can irritate your skin, obstruct your breathing and make it hard to get restorative sleep.

It can also be dangerous if you have a condition like sleep apnea, which can cause serious health problems if left untreated. If you struggle with sleep, it’s important to talk to your doctor and schedule a sleep study to diagnose the real problem and get the needed treatment.

Proffee: protein and coffee mixed

TikTokers regularly share interesting food and drinks on the app. One recent trend is mixing a protein shake with cold brew coffee to create “proffee.” Some even claim it helps them lose weight and have a healthier diet.

Is it true?

This is another trend that is unlikely to have significant health benefits. However, it also isn’t particularly harmful. It’s not likely to create weight loss on its own, and it shouldn’t replace a healthy meal that includes protein, carbs and fat.

Experts say that if you enjoy coffee mixed with a protein drink, having one isn’t likely to cause problems either. Of course, this is only true in moderation and if you don’t have any other negative health interactions with caffeine or the ingredients of a protein drink.

If you like this as a way to get your day started, that’s great, just don’t expect it to fix any health issues!

Garlic up your nose for sinus congestion?

Garlic is often touted as a home remedy for various ailments. Recently people have been on TikTok putting raw garlic cloves up their noses, claiming that it relieves sinus congestion.

Is it true?

According to doctors, it doesn’t. All you do is block your sinuses for several minutes, causing mucus to flow more quickly when you remove the garlic. Also, the smell of garlic is an irritant, which produces more mucus, not less.

Finally, if a small piece is left behind when you remove the garlic, it could cause a rash or infection, which can cause problems.

Skip the garlic and get proper care for your sinus congestion. Don’t be afraid to make an appointment at Qcare if things don’t clear up or you’re worried about a sinus infection.

Dry scooping pre-workout powder

If you’re about to go into a strenuous workout, you might consider having a pre-workout drink made by mixing protein powder with water. Some TikTok influencers are suggesting that you skip the water entirely and just eat the powder dry.

The claim is that this allows you to absorb the nutrients in the powder faster, leading to a better workout.


Is it true?

Unfortunately, this Tik Tok health trend is not only false, but it’s also very dangerous.

Dietary supplements like pre-workout powder are not heavily regulated and labels are not always accurate about what’s inside. As a result, you can ingest too much caffeine or another stimulant. This can cause heart problems and even heart attacks.

Another problem is the fine nature of the powder, which is meant to be dissolved in water. Breathing it in can damage your esophagus and lungs and may even trigger an asthma attack.

Definitely skip this one. It’s not only unhelpful, but it’s actually dangerous to your health.

Get the care you need from urgent care

If you have a health concern and questions about treatment, TikTok is not the best resource.


Instead, stop by Qcare for an appointment. You’ll talk to a qualified doctor who can give you proper medical advice.

Your health is important — protect it!

title: Allergies vs. sinusitis: What’s the Difference?
subtitle: With spring’s arrival in New York City and flowers and trees blooming – allergy season is in full effect. For some, though, sinus pressure might indicate something more serious, like a sinus infection. How can you tell the difference?
content:
With spring’s arrival in New York City and flowers and trees blooming – allergy season is in full effect. For some, though, sinus pressure might indicate something more serious, like a sinus infection. How can you tell the difference?

Allergies and sinusitis feel similar and are easy to confuse. However, the treatment is different. Knowing which one you have helps get rid of those pesky symptoms quickly and return to feeling like yourself.

Use this guide to help you understand if you’re suffering from allergies or sinusitis and what next steps you should take.

Understanding allergies

Allergies are caused by your body’s response to something specific in the environment around you, such as pollen, pet dander, mold, certain foods and more.

An allergy causes your sinuses to swell, and you may experience a runny or stuffy nose, watery or itchy eyes, sneezing and wheezing. Generally, these symptoms reduce when you’re away from the allergen and worsen when you’re near it.

There are many things in the environment that people can be allergic to, indoors and outdoors. You may also have multiple allergies, which makes pinpointing the source more challenging. Seeing a doctor can help you identify your specific allergies.

What is sinusitis?

Sinusitis is an inflammation of the sinuses that is often caused by bacteria, which means that antibiotics are an important treatment to help you get better quickly.

You may experience swelling and pain around your forehead and face, colored mucus when you cough, bad breath, a sore throat and even a fever. It’s important to see a doctor or visit an urgent care clinic to see if you have a sinus infection.

Acute sinusitis lasts a few weeks, but chronic sinusitis can last several months. If you have allergies or asthma, you’re at a higher risk of having chronic sinusitis.

Similarities and differences between allergies and sinusitis

Both allergies and sinus infections involve inflammation of the sinuses, runny nose, and coughing and sneezing. At the beginning of the illness, it can be easy to dismiss a sinus infection as being “just allergies.”

However, sinusitis has a few distinctive symptoms to watch for. Colored mucous, bad breath, and a swollen, painful feeling around the forehead and face are unique to sinus infections. Also, if you have a stuffy nose and cough that lasts for longer than a week or two or doesn’t change when your environment changes, that’s a sign to see a doctor about a sinus infection.

If you’re unsure, consider making an appointment with urgent care to get tested for sinusitis. If you have a bacterial infection, you’ll want to treat it right away to get better quickly and return to daily life.

How are allergies and sinusitis diagnosed?

What can you expect if you go to the doctor concerned about your sinuses?

If the clinician thinks you might have allergies, they’ll ask about your lifestyle, family history of allergies, and more. The doctor will then look at your ears, nose, throat, eyes and chest to see how the illness affects you, which might cause them to determine you have sinusitis rather than allergies.

Finally, several allergy tests will help you determine what you’re allergic to and how best to treat it. The doctor could do a skin prick test, blood test, patch test, or take another approach.

When diagnosing a sinus infection, the doctor will look at your ears, nose and throat to see if there are blockages and to look for signs of an infection. This usually provides enough information for the doctor to determine if you have sinusitis, but if your case is severe or complex, you may be referred to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist.

Treatments for allergies and sinusitis

To treat allergies, the doctor will suggest limiting your exposure to the allergen if possible and using a nasal steroid spray and antihistamine pills. You can explore getting allergy shots or under-the-tongue medications if your allergies don’t respond to these treatments.

Sinusitis treatment generally requires antibiotics. Oral or topical steroids can also reduce inflammation if needed. Nasal decongestants, antihistamines and nasal sprays can also help relieve symptoms as you recover.

If you have anatomical defects in your sinuses causing chronic sinusitis, surgery can be an option to give you a long-term solution.

Qcare urgent care services

Starting to feel ill right when the weather is getting nicer is not fun, but the good news is that allergies and sinusitis can be treated effectively.

If you’re experiencing sinus infection symptoms, such as pain around your forehead, eyes, and cheeks or bad breath and colored mucous, you’ll want to make an appointment with urgent care right away. Treatment will shorten your illness and help you get back to daily life quickly.

If you have allergies, our urgent care services can help you determine which treatment is best for you, from nasal sprays to antihistamines to prescription options.


Simply make an appointment or stop in — we’re here to help you enjoy spring and summer!

title: Help Soothe Your Aching Joints: Learn All About Arthritis and How To Treat It
subtitle: For May’s Arthritis Awareness Month here’s what you need to know about arthritis – what it is, the different types of pain it causes, and most importantly, what you can do to help manage debilitating symptoms.
content:
While it’s true that arthritis is more common among seniors, there are over 100 forms of arthritis, affecting people of all ages and diverse backgrounds.

For May’s Arthritis Awareness Month here’s what you need to know about arthritis – what it is, the different types of pain it causes, and most importantly, what you can do to help manage debilitating symptoms.

How Does Arthritis Feel?


Arthritis feels different for everyone. 1 in 7 Americans have arthritis, yet there are still misconceptions. Some people have typical joint stiffness and difficulty moving around. But since there are so many different types of arthritis, everyone’s experience is unique.


Arthritis pain can feel:

  • Tender

  • Achy

  • Dull

  • Sharp

  • Tingly

  • Numb

  • Burning

  • Throbbing

You might start with joint pain but progress to sharp, shooting pains as if you’re getting an electrical shock. This is a sign that you’re experiencing nerve pain. Let your doctor know or schedule a visit at Qcare.

Different Types of Arthritis Equals Different Types of Pain

The pain you feel depends on the type of arthritis you have. Let’s talk about some common forms of arthritis and how they feel.


  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative disease of the whole joint, protective cartilage of the joint, and the fluid around it. This means that these areas slowly break down. Like most types of arthritis, OA produces inflammation in the body and commonly affects knees, hips, hands, and the spine. OA pain can feel achy and tender, or your joints are grating and scraping on each other.


  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disorder where inflammation becomes overactive and the body attacks healthy tissue (often the lining of the joints). With RA you can experience a hot pain or a deep ache in your bones and feel very weak and tired.


  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) is diagnosed in childhood and is an autoimmune disorder similar to RA. It’s extremely painful, causing sharp pains and a feeling like your joints are on fire or you can’t move.

  • Gout is when the joints get inflamed because of high uric acid levels, a waste product in our blood. When the body can’t break down uric acid fast enough, it forms crystals in the joints – causing severe pain. Gout affects a specific joint, like the big toe. Flare-ups come on very suddenly, leaving the joints feeling hot, tender, and unable to be touched without severe pain.


Even though arthritis can be debilitating, there are comprehensive treatment options from medications to lifestyle changes that can help you find some pain relief.

What Are Common Arthritis Treatments?

Treatment for arthritis depends on the type of arthritis you have. For autoimmune disorders like rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis, you might need medications called disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to help reduce inflammation in your body. Biologics are another powerful drug to help stop inflammation and reduce damage to other organs.

Because every type of arthritis has a different treatment, talk to your doctor or visit a Qcare mobile clinic to discuss what’s best for you.

Some common arthritis treatments include:

  • Hot and cold therapy

  • Topical rubs

  • Physical therapy (PT) or regular physical activity

  • Corticosteroids

  • Diet changes like drinking more water or avoiding certain foods

  • Weight loss

Your treatment plan might also include visiting a specialist. If your arthritis is causing problems with your skin, eyes or other organs, your doctor may want to refer you to a specialist who can help.

Joint Pain Management Can Help

Arthritis treatment should be flexible and tailored to your specific needs. In addition to the common treatments discussed above, you can minimize pain and help protect your body with joint protection, a way to modify your body movements to avoid severe stress on the joints. For example, you can use larger joints like your forearm to carry your grocery bags rather than your fingers.

Other ways you can manage your joint pain include:

  • Using assistive devices when needed

  • Alternate between rest and activity

  • Over-the-counter medications such as acetaminophen ibuprofen and naproxen sodium

  • Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT): a type of therapy that has been proven to be effective for people managing chronic conditions because they learn to manage physical, behavioral and emotional triggers of pain.

See a Doctor For Joint Pain Today

Are you wondering if your joint pain is arthritis? Before you can be treated, you’ll need a thorough exam from a doctor to know exactly what you’re dealing with. Don’t suffer for another day. Make an appointment with Qcare today to get relief for your joint pain.

title: Ticks Suck: Here's How To Prevent Tick Bites This Season
subtitle: With the warm weather comes the concern for tick bites and tick-related illnesses.
content:
With the warm weather comes the concern for tick bites and tick-related illnesses. While you’re most likely to get a tick bite after a camping trip upstate, ticks have been found in parts of New York City such as the Bronx and Staten Island.


Ticks are starting to branch out into different locations, so they might show up when you least expect it. Since they carry viruses, bacteria and parasites it’s important to know how to prevent tick bites and what to do if you get one.


How To Prevent Tick Bites Before You Leave The House


Preventing a tick bite starts with preparing for your outing. Here are three easy ways you can prevent tick bites before you leave the house.


Know where ticks live: Understanding where ticks live is important for prevention. Woods, grassy areas and mountains are known for high tick activity. Hiking, hunting and walking on trails can increase your chances of getting a tick bite. Some resources to help assess your risk of encountering a tick are: local health departments, local news and weather forecasts and websites that map out where tick activity is the highest.

Dress for the occasion: If possible, wear long sleeve shirts and pants. Tucking your pants into socks or taping where your pants meet your socks can help prevent ticks from getting to your feet. Choosing light-colored clothing helps you easily spot a tick that attaches to you.

Spray gear with repellant: If you’re going to be in a high-tick area, you can spray your clothes and gear with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) registered insect repellents. They can be a powerful tool to keep ticks away. The best repellents will have ingredients such as DEET, permethrin or picaridin.

After Your Come Inside: Check For Ticks


After you’ve been outdoors, it’s important to inspect your body and your gear for ticks. The quicker you spot a tick or tick bite, the easier it is to deal with.


Check your clothes for ticks: You’ll want to quickly check your clothes for ticks to see if you have any on the outside. Then, wash and dry your clothes to remove ticks that might be clinging to them. Drying clothes on high heat for at least 6 minutes can help kill any you have.

Examine pets: Thoroughly examine your pets because ticks love to attach themselves to animals. Ticks can be hard to spot on pets, so a thorough check of their fur, skin and in between their paws is essential.

Give yourself a head-to-toe inspection: Giving yourself a head-to-toe inspection can help you spot a tick bite early. Taking a shower within two hours of coming inside can reduce your chances of contracting a serious illness from a tick bite.

How To Check For Tick Bites

After you take off your clothes, examine your whole body. Going from your head down to your toes is helpful so you don’t miss any parts of your body. If needed, use mirrors to see areas that are hard for you to see.

You’ll want to check:

  • Your head and hair

  • In and around your ears

  • Under your arms

  • In between your fingers

  • Around your waist (including your belly button)

  • Between your legs

  • Back of knees

  • Feet, ankles and in between toes

Ticks can easily hide in the warm crevices of the body and they’re very tiny (about the size of a poppy seed) when they bite. So look for something that’s small, brown or black in color.

How To Handle A Tick Bite

First, you’ll want to stay calm to successfully remove the tick – the quicker you remove the tick, the less likely it is that you’ll get sick.


Remove the tick: You’ll want to get tweezers and get as close to the skin as possible. Then, pull the tick out in ∫. This is important to get the whole thing out because partial removal can cause the tick to stay in and transmit illnesses to you. If you’re outdoors a lot, consider getting tick removal kits to have with you.

Save the tick: Saving the tick in a plastic bag can help identify what type of tick it is and if it’s carrying any disease-containing pathogens.

See a doctor: Getting a tick bite can be scary, see your healthcare provider or visit a Qcare mobile clinic for a thorough examination.

When To See A Doctor for a Tick Bite

It’s important to monitor yourself for symptoms after a tick bite. You should see a healthcare provider right away if:

  • You’re unsure if you got the whole tick out

  • You can’t get the tick out

  • You develop a rash in the shape of a “bulls-eye”

  • You develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, muscle aches, headache and fatigue

  • You experience muscle weakness or difficulty breathing

Remember, early treatment helps prevent serious long-term illness. If you have any questions or concerns after a tick bite, visit a Qcare clinic today. Simply walk in or make an appointment. We’re here to answer all your tick-related questions.
